Responsive options

To help readability, websites need to be readable at different widths.
CSimple has options to help rearrange elements to make them more readable on phones, tablets, and laptops.

Intro to Responsive Widths

The page layout can change based on the width of the web browser. There are three major widths Based on a small device like a phone, a medium device like a tablet, and large devices like your desktop. The variables file defines the breakpoint width for medium and large breakpoints. Any browser less wide than the medium breakpoint is small, and any browser wider than the large breakpoint is considered large. By default, medium breakpoint 700 pixels wide, and the large breakpoint is 1000 pixels wide.


Responsive Breakpoints
					
$breakpoint-medium-width: 700px;
$breakpoint-large-width: 1000px;

Responsive Typography

As the viewpoint shrinks, the text will get smaller and the line height will increase. This makes the text easier to read on smaller devices. Here the default values:


Responsive Font Settings
				
$small-breakpoint-font-size: 1em;
$small-breakpoint-line-height: 1.125;
$medium-breakpoint-font-size: 1.1em;
$medium-breakpoint-line-height: 1;
$large-breakpoint-font-size: 1.2em;
$large-breakpoint-line-height: 1;

Columns

The elements on a row can change their width depending on the width of the browser. Include a column width class with the s, m, or l suffix. This means the column will be that wide at that breakpoint. For example, the code snippet shows a element that will always be three columns wide, except at the small breakpoint where it will be six columns wide.


Responsive Column widths
					
<div class="row">
  <div class="content-secondary col6l col3m col2">
6 columns at desktop<br>
3 columns at tablet<br>
2 columns at phone<br>
	</div>
</div>

6 columns at laptop
3 columns at tablet
2 columns at phone

Element Visibility

You can specify when elements are visible at certain breakpoint widths. For example, add the display-m class to specify the element is only visible at medium breakpoints. You can combine the display-s, display-m, and display-l classes to specify an element is only visible at certain breakpoints.

In this example code, we have a long description used in medium and large displays while small browsers get a succinct summary.


Visibiity at different widths
						
<div class="row">
  <div class="content-tertiary display-l col6">
You can see this element on large displays(like laptops).
  </div>
  <div class="content-tertiary display-m col6">
You can see this element on medium displays(like tablets).
  </div>
  <div class="content-tertiary display-s col6">
You can see this element on small displays(like phones).
  </div>
</div>

You can see this element on large displays(like laptops).
You can see this element on medium displays(like tablets).
You can see this element on small displays(like phones).
